Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Dexterous Manipulation Attained Using Task-Specific Admittance Realized with Variable Impedance Actuation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project establishes a sound engineering framework for designing next-generation robots and intelligent robotic devices that can be used to perform difficult manipulation tasks quickly and reliably. The framework is useful both for traditional robots already installed in manufacturing plants and future "soft robots" that will make human-robot collaboration safe. The focus is on constrained manipulation problems such as assembly and repair tasks, many of which are dull, difficult, and dangerous. The results will allow robots to be more effectively used in a wide range of domains such as service, healthcare, space exploration, and manufacturing.

The project yields a means to simultaneously control both a robot's position and its elastic behavior using kinematically redundant arms driven by actuators with controllable stiffness. It will be demonstrated that proper design of the robot path plan and admittance plan will ensure that constraints imposed by manipulation tasks are accommodated and high-level task objectives are reliably satisfied despite uncertainies (e.g., the door is opened, the assembly is completed properly). The four planned major outcomes of this research program are: 1) general procedures for selecting the optimal manipulation plan (identifying the optimal motion and admittance plans) using numerical procedures to ensure that the specified manipulation task progresses quickly, appropriately, and reliably despite uncertainties, 2) procedures for realizing a specified admittance plan involving the use of a redundant serial manipulator with variable impedance actuation (a series elastic actuator with controllable stiffness) at each joint, 3) a demonstration of improved robot dexterity in constrained manipulation tasks using redundant serial manipulators with variable impedance actuation to verify the manipulation plan selection methods and validate the overall manipulation approach, and 4) a library of constrained generic task categories with associated optimal manipulation plans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project overall objective is to give robotic arms human-like dexterity by modifying their joints so that their passive elastic behavior (compliance) can be continuously controlled when performing a constrained task, such as opening a door or turning a crank. 

Conventional robots have very stiff links and joints to provide accurate positioning when not constrained in any way.  In order to regulate contact forces when performing constrained manipulation tasks, it is well known that some form of passive compliance is necessary. Because conventional robots do not have this compliance, they are seldom used in these types of tasks.  If a constrained task is attempted with a conventional robot, some form of passive compliance is added to the distal end of the robot (the end-effector) in a wrist or other end-of-arm tooling.  The desired end-of-arm tooling is normally designed and built for each specific application.  If the application is changed, the end-of-arm tooling also needs to be redesigned and changed, making the robot system changeover slow and expensive.  Also, applications that require the compliance to change as the task progresses cannot be attempted using this conventional approach.

The approach used in this project is to put controllable compliance into the joints of the robot arm, a property similar to what humans attain using antagonist muscle co-activation.  In unconstrained applications, the compliance would be adjusted to be very stiff, like a conventional robot, for highly accurate positioning.  In constrained applications, the compliance could be adjusted so that it has low stiffness in constrained directions (for force regulation) and high stiffness in unconstrained directions (for accurate positioning).  Because the compliance is controllable, the appropriate compliance potentially could be adjusted for use in any specified task or could be altered as needed during the task.

Components of the work included: 1) developing systematic procedures for selecting the appropriate end-effector compliance for a specified constrained task, 2) developing procedures for converting the task-appropriate end-effector compliance into the appropriate mechanical behavior at each joint of a serial manipulator, and 3) developing a demonstration of improved robot dexterity using a redundant serial manipulator having novel variable stiffness actuators at each joint to verify the compliance selection procedures and validate the manipulation approach.

Work in the area of compliance selection yielded a computer program that will identify the compliance that is optimal for performing any specified simple task such as operating a crank, opening a door, or polishing a surface when there are known bounds on the uncertainties in the desired path.

Work in the area of converting the desired end-effector compliance into the appropriate joint compliances has yielded many outcomes, including new theoretical results and new computer programs. The limits on the end-effector compliances that can be achieved with different types of manipulators have been identified for planar robots having 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 joints and for spatial robots having 6 joints.  Procedures for identifying where robot joints must be located to achieve a specified compliance have also been developed for each of these robot types.  Programs to generate a path in both joint position and joint compliance so that a robot realizes the desired end-effector compliance as it executes a task have also been developed.

Work in the area of developing a demonstration of this new type of manipulation strategy has yielded new hardware capable of adjusting its compliance in real-time.  The variable stiffness actuator designed as part of this project is capable of changing the stiffness of the joint by a factor of 10,000. The joint stiffness is able to change from effectively zero stiffness to the stiffness of the link in less than a tenth of a second.  A serial robot consisting of 3 joints of this type has been built and tested.  Results show that the robot is able to turn a crank to lift a relatively heavy weight with small interaction forces in the constrained directions despite significant error in the commanded path.
